Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This research seeks to develop new colloidal diluted magnetic semiconductor quantum dots and quantum dot heterostructures for fundamental research and potential application in spin-based electronics or photonics technologies. Synthetic, analytical, and spectroscopic techniques will be integrated to optimize new physical phenomena and develop fundamental structure/function relationships for this emerging class of materials. Specific research objectives include:
(i) development and investigation of new synthetic routes for preparing high-quality doped inorganic chalcogenide nanostructures
(ii) detailed investigation of syntheses by application of dopant-specific spectroscopic probes in combination with mass spectrometry and other analytical techniques
(iii) description of doped quantum dot electronic structures by application of an array of advanced spectroscopic and magneto-spectroscopic techniques
(iv) development and demonstration of new structural motifs for spin manipulation in semiconductor nanocrystals

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This research will combine innovations in chemical preparative methodologies with sophisticated optical and magneto-optical measurements in order to understand and harness the physical properties of new magnetic semiconductor nanostructures relevant to spin-based information processing technologies. In addition to yielding new fundamental scientific insights and new materials, this research will also provide undergraduate and graduate students with opportunities for advanced interdisciplinary education and training in technologically important areas in order to prepare them for future careers in science and engineering. Students will participate in UW's interdisciplinary Nanotechnology PhD program, will gain valuable exposure to our national laboratories through user facilities, and will gain valuable experience with international collaborations involving scientists and engineers interested in applications of these materials in locations as diverse as Brazil, Germany, India, the Netherlands, Canada, Spain, the Republic of Korea, and Switzerland. Emphasis will be placed on integration of research and education at the undergraduate level through aggressive involvement of undergraduates in the research, incorporation of experiments and concepts from the research into the UW undergraduate laboratory curriculum, and collaboration with faculty and students from undergraduate institutions across the country.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Doped semiconductor nanostructures are ubiquitous in energy conversion, energy storage, and photocatalysis technologies, as well as in information processing and storage technologies, and are central to numerous futuristic proposed device technologies most notably in the area of spintronics. This project has focused on the development of new doped semiconductor nanostructures, and has investigated the new photophysical and spectroelectrochemical properties of these doped nanocrystals using sophisticated instrumentation and advanced theoretical techniques. The research has balanced synthetic, spectroscopic, spectroelectrochemical, and analytical research efforts to develop new colloidal intermediate-gap doped semiconductor nanocrystals (or quantum dots, QDs) and nanocrystal heterostructures for fundamental investigation and potential application in energy or information technologies. Synthetic, analytical, and spectroscopic techniques were integrated to optimize materials displaying new physical properties, and to develop new fundamental understanding of synthesis and electronic structure/function relationships for this important class of materials. Specific research accomplishments include development and investigation of new synthetic routes for preparing colloidal transition-metal-doped intermediate-gap chalcogenide QDs (e.g., Mn2+- or Co2+-doped CdSe, Cd1-xZnxSe, CdTe QDs) and related nanocrystal heterostructures, detailed investigation of syntheses by application of dopant-specific spectroscopic probes in combination with other analytical techniques, description of doped QD electronic structures by application of advanced spectroscopic and magneto-spectroscopic techniques, development and demonstration of new structural motifs for spin or energy manipulation in semiconductor QDs. Specific scientific discoveries include intrinsic dual emission via exciton storage in colloidal Mn2+-doped semiconductor nanocrystals, electrically controlled Auger de-excitation of Mn2+ in doped nanocrystals, redox brightening of luminescent nanocrystals, saturable luminescence in doped nanocrystals, thermal inversion of semiconductor magneto-optics, theoretical basis for electron-dopant magnetic exchange coupling, and high-temperature magneto-optical polaron dynamics. This program has yielded new materials and fundamental electronic structure/function relationships that will significantly impact the way such materials are understood and potentially applied in future energy and information processing technologies.

 

In addition to yielding new fundamental scientific insights and products, this program has also provided advanced interdisciplinary education and training to students in the areas of inorganic, physical, and materials chemistries at the University of Washington. Emphasis has been placed on integration of research and education at the undergraduate level through involvement of undergraduates in the proposed research and collaboration with faculty from undergraduate institutions, including hosting such faculty and their undergraduate students as visiting scientists at UW. Participating students have collaborated with researchers at national labs and international universities, and have been involved in UW's interdisciplinary Nanotechnology PhD Program, providing them with valuable exposure to other research experiences and scientific cultures. These experiences have contributed to preparing participating undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers for future careers in science, engineering, and education.
